text.p: The following are the main stories from Wednesday morning's Austrian newspapers:
DER STANDARD

- Conservative junior coalition partner leader Wolfgang Schuessel has said that a sale of the government's 70 percent stake in Creditanstalt to Bank Austria would be a breach of coalition agreements on privatisation.

- Both Social Democrat Chancellor Franz Vranitzky and Finance Minister Viktor Klima have said they would only sell Creditanstalt to Bank Austria if it was the highest bidder, in line with European Union law.
- All interested parties in the sale of Creditanstalt have said they would hand over the money for the bank before the end of the year.
- A plan for Bank Austria's takeover of Creditanstalt is ready. The first step would be for the two banks' subsidiaries to merge.
- Should former supermarket owner Karl Wlaschek win the bid for Creditanstalt it is likely he would later float the bank on the stock market.
- Die Erste savings bank expects a higher dividend as the operating profit should rise by about 10 percent.
- Tyrolean Airways' pre-tax profits are expected to rise to 77 million schillings in 1996 after 32.8 million schillings the previous year.
DIE PRESSE
- The consortium around insurer EA-Generali plans to put up two billion schillings as risk capital for setting up new enterprises.
- Pension funds will be available to entrepreneurs from January 1 1997. Austria's twelve pension funds currently manage 27.3 billion schillings.
- While the merger of insurers Bundeslaender and Austria-Collegialitaet nears completion, Bundeslaender's major share-holder Raiffeisen bank is eyeing a takeover of postal savings bank PSK.
KURIER
- Karl Wlaschek intends to run Creditanstalt more economically should his bid for the bank be successful.
- In exchange for Bank Austria's takeover of Creditanstalt, Die Erste savings bank could receive the majority stake in GiroCredit, the paper says.
- The offer for Creditanstalt by the consortium around EA-Generali and Die Erste savings bank lies at around 15 billion schillings, the newspaper says.

- Burgenland Holding, major share holder in provincial energy providers burgenlaendische Erdgasversorgung and burgenlaendische Elektrizitaet, reported a fall in pre-tax profits from 413.5 million schillings to 174.3 million schillings.
SALZBURGER NACHRICHTEN
- Creditanstalt boss Guido Schmidt-Chiari favours a merger with Die Erste savings bank.
WIRTSCHAFTSBLATT
- Papermaker KNP Leykam will receive a three billion schilling loan from the European Investmentbank to expand capacity.
